conclusion: Determine the vertical distance by which the point light source S must be moved upward so that the light emitted from S is just not visible above the water surface.
Use Snell's law and geometric properties to find the required distance.
The radius of the circular board is r.
The depth of the point light source S below the center O of the board is H = sqrt(3)r.
The refractive index of the liquid is n = sqrt(2).
The light ray from S passes through the center O of the board and is incident on the water surface at an angle theta.
The distance from S to O is sqrt(r^2 + H^2) = sqrt(4r^2) = 2r.
The angle of incidence theta can be found using trigonometry: tan theta = sqrt(3) implies theta = 60 degrees.
Using Snell's law: sqrt(2) sin theta_1 = sin theta_2, and since theta_2 = 90 degrees, sin theta_1 = sqrt(2)/2 implies theta_1 = 45 degrees.
The angle of incidence theta_1 is 45 degrees.
The distance from S to the water surface is d, and the angle of incidence theta_1 = 45 degrees implies d = h.
Using the geometry of the right triangle: tan 45 degrees = h/r implies h = r.
The total distance from S to the water surface is sqrt(h^2 + r^2) = r sqrt(2).
The vertical distance moved is 2r - r sqrt(2) = r(2 - sqrt(2)).
The correct vertical distance moved is H - h = sqrt(3)r - r = r(sqrt(3) - 1).
